text.p: These are some of the leading stories in the Greek Cypriot press on Tuesday. Reuters has not verified these reports and does not vouch for their accuracy.
- A Greek Cypriot man with a leg injury in photo taken at a Turkish hospital in 1974 has been identified as one of the 1,619 persons missing since the invasion.
- Interest rates go down by half a percentage point from today.
- The health ministry orders an inquiry into the death of a 10-year-old initially diagnosed as having a stomach virus but died on Saturday after emergency surgery for a blocked colon.
- Ombudsman received a record number of complaints in 1996.
- Trade unionists get together for an all-island forum on labour issues.
- Foreign students are lured to Cyprus on false promises that they will be able to work while they study, immigration officials say.
- Island-wide trade unions conference gets underway.
- Foreign Minister Alecos Michaelides is discontented with President Glafcos Clerides because another government official is being promoted to a high-ranking post in right-wing Disy party.

- Greece and Turkey will be excluded from a multinational force which may be deployed on the island in the event of a solution to the Cyprus issue because their presence could cause functional difficulties, western military experts say.
- A meeting is scheduled at the presidential palace today to handle the crisis in Disy.
- The death of 10-year-old Tasos Pieri causes a dispute among doctors on who is to blame for not diagnosing his condition in time.
